titlestmt.titleproper: Goldstone (N.J. "Bud") collection on Simon Rodia's Towers
Finding Aid for the N.J. "Bud" Goldstone collection on Simon Rodia's Towers LSC.1317
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laurel McPhee with assistance from Robert Whalley in thr Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2005; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√© and edited by Laurel McPhee and Amy Shung-Gee Wong.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-08 15:15:31 -0700.

did.unittitle: N.J. "Bud" Goldstone collection on Simon Rodia's Towers
did.abstract: N.J. "Bud" Goldstone was a professional engineer and member of the Committee for Simon Rodia's Towers in Watts, Inc. In 1959, he designed and executed an engineering test that proved the Towers' structural safety. The bulk of the collection consists of Goldstone's detailed photographs and negatives of the Towers, documenting a restoration project completed between 1994 and 2002. The collection also includes the original 1959 structural integrity report and test plan, a set of microfiche from the City of Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Department, and additional photographic materials.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], N.J. "Bud" Goldstone Collection on Simon Rodia's Towers (Collection 1317). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Laurel McPhee with assistance from Robert Whalley in thr Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2005.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Simon Rodia's Towers were constructed between 1921 and 1955 in the Watts area of Los Angeles. Built single-handedly by Rodia, an Italian immigrant, the Towers consist of an elaborate walled enclosure containing seventeen sculptures of thin steel members covered with mortar. The sculptures' surfaces are decorated with a mosaic of tiles, glass shards and objects. Rodia deeded the property to a neighbor in 1955 when he left Los Angeles to live in the Northern California town of Martinez. After 1955, the towers were neglected and fell into disrepair. The City of Los Angeles Department of Building and Safety determined the Towers were a public safety hazard in 1957 and ordered their demolishment. The Committee for Simon Rodia's Towers in Watts, Inc. (CSRTW) was immediately formed in an attempt to save the Towers. After a demolition hearing, the City agreed to a lateral stress test, spearheaded by aerospace engineer N.J. "Bud" Goldstone, at the Committee's expense. On October 10, 1959, Goldstone executed a successful proof-load test, demonstrating the Towers' structural stability. Goldstone continued to serve as a member and an officer of CSRTW from 1960 to 1970, and worked to advance the issue of preserving and restoring the Towers through the 1990s. In 1975, the Committee, which had preserved the Towers independently for 16 years, gave the Towers and Art Center to the City of Los Angeles for operation and maintenance. In 1978, the Towers were deeded to the State of California. The State undertook an extensive restoration project, but in 1985, responsibility for the Towers was again assumed by the City of Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Department. Repair to damage caused in the 1994 Northridge earthquake was commenced in 1995 and completed in 2001. The Towers are listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and are the location of cultural programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection consists of N.J. "Bud" Goldstone's detailed photographs and negatives of the Towers, documenting a restoration project completed between 1994 and 2002. The collection also includes the original 1959 structural integrity report and test plan; a set of microfiche from the City of Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Department, documenting their survey of the Towers before restoration; and a set of transparencies by Los Angeles photographer Mitzi Trumbo.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
City of Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Department microfiche, ca. 1995-2001.
Photographs by N.J. "Bud" Goldstone, ca. 1994-2002.
Miscellaneous, 1959-2000.

separatedmaterial.head: Items Removed from the Collection
separatedmaterial.p: A bibliography of printed works on Simon Rodia's Towers compiled by N.J. "Bud" Goldstone was removed from the collection, and added to the collection file. Available upon request at the Department of Special Collections, UCLA.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Committee for Simon Rodia's Towers in Watts Records (Collection 1388). Available at Department of Special Collections, UCLA.

did.unittitle: Series I: City of Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Dept. microfiche

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Microfiche transparencies documenting the restoration of Simon Rodia's Towers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Microfiche: East Tower; Floor 0-1 to 0-13, and A Tower; Gazebo levels A, B, and C- with house and chimney; North Wall interior, BBQ, oven and canopy; South Wall interior levels A-C, with ship of Marco Polo and B Tower; South Wall outside levels A-C, and B Tower.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Microfiche: Center Tower 01-82 repair, 83-137 repair, and 138-155 repair; East Tower 1 05-28 repair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Microfiche of the three tall towers: Levels A-X.

did.unittitle: Series II: Photographs by N.J. "Bud" Goldstone

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs and negatives documenting Simon Rodia's Towers and the restoration project following the 1994 Northridge Earthquake. The photographs are arranged according to Goldstone's original index to the collection, which abscribed a unique number to each set of photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous photographs, slides, printed materials, and technical documents relating to Simon Rodia's Towers. Includes the original 1959 structural integrity report and test plan, and a set of slide transparencies by Los Angeles photographer Mitzi Trumbo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 460 mounted 35mm color transparencies. Many of the photos are by N.J. "Bud" Goldstone (and include duplicates of images of in Series 2).
